div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.

div.head: Malaria Curse in Greece
div.p: A paper on Malaria in Greeoe was read on Friday week before the Oxford Medical Sooiety by Major Ronald Rosv, F.R8., Profe»sor of Tropical Medicine in the Uuiversity of Liverpool. Dr. O.ler, Regies Professor if Medicine at Oxford, presided, and there was a large and diatingniihed audience.

After referring to the general physiography ol Greeoe, Professor Ross desoribed the valley > f Lake Kopais in Bmotis, which was the soene tf his recent study ol malaria in Greece. The looality, he said, was the dried-op bed of a large lake wh ch had been drained in remote times by tbe neighbouring inhabitants. In the Middle Agu the drainage works foil oot of repsir and ihi area became a marsh. Reoently its restoration was taken in hand by a French oompany. which had suboeqoently given place to the Lake Kopaia Cotnpauy, a British oon- corn. Tbe bed of the auoient lake was now a great plain covered with crops of all kinds, bat malaria was so deatractive there that the oompany lately commissioned bim to investigate it, with a view to the adoption of preventive measares. He began by examining the iuhabitants of the villages ahioh stand on the margin ot the plaiD, for tbe purpose of estimating the prevalence of the diteise. This was done by ascertaining the proportion of those having enlarged spleens and those in whose blood the parasite is found oot of a given number. Children, who are more affected than adults, were chit lly examined. Tbe result itigatiug five localities, includieg Thebes, now a town of about 5,000 iuhabitants, to establish a minimum malaria rate among ohildren ol between 25.5 per cent, and 40.9 per oent. In the worst plaoes ex im:n- ed all the cb lJteu. in Professor Rtss'b opinion, wonl 1 probably bo found infected in tbs autumn. Most of them were far ftom well and some looked m-ssrably ill, emaciated, and anemia He bat obtained the following approximate statistics for the whole of Greece: — Population, 2.433,806 ; average annual number of oasos, 250,00); average annnal number of death', 1,76»; oases doriug 1905, 960,018; deaths during 1905, 5,916. The type of disease was severe; pernicious attacks were very oomand the most serious form, known as

mons. He considered the diaeaae rxtremely, if not shockingly, rife in the oiontry -much more so even than in Italy. • According to statiat os prepared by Dr. 8avas, the number of oases and deaths was half again as large as in Italy for rqnai numbers of people. What most be the effect of this obiqnitoos and oonstant imnbos of disease on the people of modern Greece! The malady was essentially one of inlanoy among the native population. Infecting the child one or two years after birth, it persecuted bim nntil puberty with a loog sne- oe*si in of febrile attack* accompanied by mnoh splenomegaly and at emia. What woold be the effeot upon oar population if to the ordinary transient fevers were addod a malady which asta for years and m*y sometimes attack every ohild in a village! Passing on to consider the political, eoonomicaL and historical aigni- fioance ol malaria. Professor Rosa pointed oot that it mast have existed in Greeoe ever since the time of HippocTatee abont 400 bc. He suggested that it had been introdnred by Asiatio and African slaves and had fallen like a blight on ibe populous, vigorous, and highly- oivilited land of Greece, gradually sapping away the energies of the race by attacking the rural population He was ooLfidant that cause* such as malaria, dysenteiy. and intestinal eolozoa most have modified history to a much greater extent than we oonoeived. He attributed the laok of population, the backwardness, sod poverty of modern Greeoe to the same cause. Its reputation for oohealthinese kept travellers away, the innkeeper hesitated abont •pending bis capital in a looality where he and his children might expeot to be frequently ill; and there weie no country house*. The whole life of Greeoe most suffer from this weight which oroshed its rural population. When the children aoffored so maob, how coold the ooantry create that fresh blood which keeps a nation yooog t But for a hamlet hare and there, the famous and onoe populous valley* of Greece were deserted. He doubted if it wss the Tork who had dooe that, and thoogbt it was very largely the malarix He' ooncloded by •lisonssirg the remedy. Of the several ways of dealing w.th malaria the one ha preferred was the old Roman plan of drainage, with this mportant advantage that they had not to drain the whole sorface bat only the small pools in which the anophelines bree I. It was specially applioable to Greece. The rainy leason was the winter when the mosquitoes do not breed ; in the arid summer hey coold find only few suitable breeding pools, which coold be rendered uninhabitable to the larvs by drainage, filling op, deepening, dragging the weeds, and, in the last resort, by periodio oiling. Where carried oot with intelligence and loyalty, as in Havana, the Federated Malay 8tatee, and limailia, the work had been e*sy and cheap and the results most brilliant. He thought that Greeoe wonld be still easier to deal with. The Grecian Malaria Society had oommenoed the wurk with energy ; it had investigated local conditions, had issned instructions to the people, nrged railway oom- i-atiies to aoreen station*, and Government to ndertake drainage. He was sore the Government woold do its best to support the society, but there were many obstacle*, and ha bad ••iggeated that we in Britain might help. Tbe Liverpool School of Tropioal Medicine had ffared its assistance, which bad been accepted by tbq King ot Greeoe. A list cf supporters h d been opened and already ioolcdod many eminent name*, beginning with the Greek Minister in London, the British Minister in Athens, the Presidents of the Royal Society, the British Academy, the Royal College of Physicians, and many Greeks residing in London. Any o:e wishing to join woold be welcomed, and bad only to write to him or to the secretary Mr. A.H Milne, B. 10, Exchange buildings. Liverpool
The Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine 1> a issued an appeal on behalf of the scheme, which is under the patronage of Piincess Christian.

div.head: A. S C
div.p: The A. 8. 0. polo-ground will be flooded tomorrow and the next day.

div.head: New Children's 8ohool.
div.p: The new school for children fonnded by Mohamed Pasha Faidi will open on the 1st prox.

div.head: San Stefano Casino
div.p: The San Stefano Casino dosed yesterday for works of extension, which will be ended in April next.

div.head: French Deputies
div.p: The election of a second dependent nation will take place on December 1 at the French Com ulate, Cairo.

div.head: Mecca Pilgrimage.
div.p: The Mohamedan pilgrims who had arrived at Mecca up to the beginning of last week numbered 29,000.

div.head: Helouan Railway.
div.p: We are requested to bring to the notice of oar readers that train No. 46 on the Helouan Branch will in fatare stop at Meadi station.

div.head: Al Azhar Rectorship.
div.p: Shaikh PIassoona el Nawawi has we hear, accepted the post of Rector of Al Azhar. A Khedivial decree to this effect will be published very shortly.

div.head: Legislative Counoll.
div.p: Morkos Bey Someikeb, a Coptic notable of Cairo, will probably be appointed as permanent member of the Legislative Council in place of Bassili Paeba Tadros.

div.head: Khedivial Sporting Club.
div.p: With the kind permission of the Officers Commanding, Regimental Bands will play at the Khedivial Sporting Clnb, Tuesdays and Thursdays, throughout the season.

div.head: Pert 8ald Casworks.
div.p: By the terms of an agreement, the Suez Canal Company takes over the gasworks and plant of Messrs. Lebon & Cie. at Port Said. New gasworks are to be erected at Rassowa, on the shore of Lake Met zaleh.

div.head: Gunboat at Port 8ald.
div.p: H.M.'s gunboat Merlin, from Malta, arrived on Saturday morning at Port Siid, and sailed at 5 p.m. for the Red Sea. The Merlin, Captain John J. Parry, is of 316 02 tons displacement, with 1400 H.P., and an armament of foar gaDs; her crew numbers 134 men.

div.head: Hashish Seizure
div.p: Five sacks-of hashish, which it is presumed were thrown overboard from a vessel entering Alexandria harboar on Thursday l ight, were J found by the Coast Guards in the water near j Agamd yesterday after a two days' search. The sacks contained about 250 kilos of the drog.

div.head: Merohant Seamen's Home
div.p: During the past week arrangements were made for taking in the ert-w, 25 all told, of the ; S.S. King Q.yffudd from Cardiff, which vessel ^ had beea sold to a Greek syndicate, and was paid off and delivered over to the new owners at Alexandria after di-charging. Also, in the months of August and September batches of men were received into the Home under somewhat similar circumstances.

div.head: Fire In Cairo.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon a serions fire broke out in Sharia el Houayati, Cairo, near where the old Native Court of Appeal used to be. The damage done to the native dwellings concerned was not serious nor acoompanied by any loss of life. The police and fire brigade were soon on the spot, but owing to the insufficiency of fire plugs the water had to be brought from a considerable distance.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: Between November 16 and 18, 44 vessels, 21 northward and 23 southward bound, transited the Canal and paid transit and passenger toll Fr. 1,164,514.48. Of these vessel-, 26 were British, 12 German, 1 Italian, 1 Dutch, 1 Japanese, 1 Spanish, and 2 French. The total revenue since November 1 is Fr. 6,167,7M.10. During this period, 195 vessels transited the Canal, 94 northward and 101 southward bound.

div.head: "The World" and Egypt
div.p: The Egyptian supplemeut of ''The World" issue of November is one of the most complete, comprehensive, and up-to-date brochures on the subject which has come to our notice. The information supplied therein should prove most useful to those intending to pay their first visit to the country ; while those who already know it will appreciate the wellcompiled Beries of artiolea on the social advantages, sporting facilities, and health-giving properties of Egypt, and the fine photogravures and illaatratiooa which accompany them. The Egyptian letters which appeared inthe columns of "The World" last winter were some of the best of their kiud, and this late Egyptian supplement should make this well-established journal more popnlar thaD ever wi'h those whose interests are connected with the Near East.

div.head: KORDOFAN
THE SIRDAR'S INSPECTION
div.p: Today the Sirdar is lpaving Khartoum on a tonr of inspection thronghont the remote Sudanese province of Kordofan The area of this province is no less than 167,000 square miles. The southern districts, which are inhabited by Nubas, still frequently disturbed as the natives rather enjoy a fight, but in other parts of thin country the sitnation is more satisfactory. The revenue is increasing owing to the return of large numbers of the former inhabitants from the Eastern provinces where they went in Dervish times, and to the opening up of trade routes to the Bahr el Ghbzal and Darfonr. Sir Reginald Wingate in the conrse of his tour of inspeotion intends to visit the capital town, E1 Obeid.

His tour will have a good effect in helping to impress the minds of the population with the power of the Goveroment to maintain order in the southern district*. There exist many mountains in the Souih which have never yet been visited by a Government official. The raids between the inhabitants of the various Jobels have led to many acts of savagery. Their chief overthinks will not come to see the nearest inspector, and this shyness appears to be due more to fear of the unknown than totbederireof resisting the Government. Their knowledge of the onstoms of Governments in no way has tended to make them over-confident in a new Government, of which they know nothing.

div.head: TALODI CAMPAIGN.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive has beon graciously pleased to confer the 3rd class of the Osmanieh Order on Miralai O'Connell Bey, who was in : oommand of the force which suppressed the 1 rebellion at Talodi iu Southern Kordofan. TJie i 4th olasa of the same Order has boen conferred ! on Kaimakam D. H. Leveaon, Intelligence j officer to the expedition.

div.head: THE SUDAN BUDGET.
div.p: The Sudan Budget for next year has now j been balanced. No additional grants have been made. The receipts and expenditure will ! amount to about L.E 20,'\000jmore than last year. The total expenditure has been placed at L E. 1,200,000, including the contribution from Egypt.

div.head: SUDAN NOTES.
div.p: According to the "Sudan Times," the special train conveying the Governor General arrived at Khartoum North in the early morning on Friday week. A * previously announced his Excellency's reception was private in compliance with his wishes.
Atsunrisebis Excellency orossod the river to the British barracks, where the troops were reviewed in honour of tli9 birthday of his Msjesty the King.

In the evening a banquet was given at the Palace to which were invited the heads of Departments, the 0.0. the British troops and seme of his offioers, the offioers commanding the Egyptian troops in Khartoum 3tation, some notab'ep, and ulema.
E!-Lewa Baron Sir R. von Slatin Pasha, Inspector General, left for Kordofan la6t week.
Winter weather has set in, and people in the Sudan are enjoying the cool and fresh breeze of the North after a long summer.

A correspondent writes to the "SadaD Timea" So much has been written by you in praise of the progressiveuesa of the Sadan Gjvemment, that another instance of its eagerness to be op-todate wi 1 not be oat of place. Wbilo the Eugliah-speaking race has scarcely recovered from the shock which tbe announcement of President Roosevelt's spelling reform occasioned, we find the Steamers and Boats Department has already adopted the uew system, and one can see on its tariff board ou the Khartoum-Halfuya ferry, the words "Midiam" and "Purcil "

div.head: AN ANGLO-ABYSSINIAN COMPANY.
EGYPTIAN CONCERN INTERESTED.
div.p: The E'biopian Rainproof Monopoly Company (Limited) has b9en formed, inter alia, to acquire a concession granted hy His Imperial Msjjsty Menelik II., Emperor of Ethiopia, for a period i f twenty-five years, from April 9. 1906, coi ferrirg the sole right to import and sell iu Abyssinia all kiuda of water proof cotton goods and other rain proof material. The company will also take over the full benefit cf all contracts, engagements, rights, privileges, and all other property and i fleets to which the vendors are entitled iu relation to their business of Ethiopian merchants now carried on by them in Abyssinia and iu Manchester, under the style of 'The Ethiopian Rainproof Monopoly Company." The capital is £100.f'( 0. in Ordinary shares of £1 each. Bgyptian Options (Limi'ed) invite subscriptions at par for 60,000 shares. 25,( 00 of which have been underwritten. The purchase price has been fixed at £42.500, payable as to £37,500 in fully paid ►hares ot the company, and the balauoe of £5,000, as to b'»'f tb$,amount thereof in oash or fi 1 y paid shareV, or partly in each at the option of the vendors, and as to the remeinirg ! half at tho option of the directors.

div.head: UNITED EGYPTIAN LANDS, LTD.
div.p: The United Egyptian Linds, Limited, will shortly he fl »vtpd simnltaneo1 sly in Egypt end England. The capital will-be £5FO.OOO, ai d there will be some deferred shares.

div.head: Army of Occupation.
Forthcoming Moves.
div.p: The married families, 2nd Battalion Royal Berks. Regiment, will vacate their present quarters at the Citadel, Cairo, on the 28th in9t., and will be accommodated in "temporary quarters" at the Citadel, pending embarkation with their unit for India.
The 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers will move from the Citadel into oarnp at Abbassieh on the 2Hth inst.

The 1st Battalion King's Own Soottish Borderers will disembark from the transport Dongola at Alexandria on the 1st prox., on joining the Egypt Command from England, and will proceed by special train to Cairo as soon as possible after disembarkation.
They will be q uartered at the Citadel, taking over the barracks which will have been vaoated by the 1st Battalion Lancashire Fasiliers.

The 2nd Battalion Royal Berks. Regiment will proceed by epeoial train from Abbassieh siding, at about 6 p.m., on the 2nd prox., to S 'ez Dooks, there to embark the following day in the transport Dongola for conveyance to India (Kartiobi).
The details, 2nd Battalion Royal Berks. Regiment, under orders to proceed to England, will embark for home between the 14th and 18th prox.
No. 2 Company, Royal Engineers, will move from Kasr-el Nil into oamp at Abbassieh on the 4th prox., for their annual oourse of field training.

The 1st Battalion Lancashire Fasiliers will proceed by speoial train from Abbassieh Siding, at about 6 p.m., on the 13th prox., to Alexandria quays, there to embark the following day in the transport Braemar Castle, for conveyance to Malta.

The time expired men, and details 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers, noted for home, will move with the battalion, embarking in the same vessel as their nnit, for conveyance to England (Southampton).
A draft of about 230 N.C.O.'s and men, K.O.8.B., from Aden, will disembark at Soez on the 17th Deoember, ex transport Assaye, and will proceed from thence to Cairo, to join the 1st battalion.

div.head: CAIRO COMPOSITOR8' STRIKE.
div.p: A strike is reported among the typesetters ofthe"Pyramide3"and 'La BouraeEgyptienne," owing, it is stated, to the introduction of linotype maohines.

div.head: CAIRO MIXED COURTS.
div.p: We learn that it is probable that M. 'fhitfbaud, prooureur de la Rdpublique at Dieppe, will succeed M. Fruni&reaaa President of the Cairo Mixed Courts.

div.head: MR. ROBERTSON'S VISIT.
div.p: "Al Mokattam's" publication of a conversation between its editor and Mr. John Robertson, M R, is deoidedly interesting. Mr. Robertson, we are amused to learn, deolares that the report of his approaohing visit to Egypt is absolutely unfounded, and asoribes its invention to the ' Egyptian Gazette." We should like to point out that we received this interesting piece of information from "Al Lewa," and that Mr. John Robertson, M.P., has only to thank Mu9tapha Pasha Kamel's organ for the malentendu.

div.head: THE DISAPPEARANCE OF ISIS.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Paris, Saoday 10.

The Egyptian goddess Isis, whose reoent disappearance from the galleries ot the Luuvre his oaused so many heart-burnings, has, it seems, at last been run to earth. So, at any rate, a writer in the "Temps" presumes, since the finding of the most remarkable stowaway ever known in the bold of a steamer recently arrived atTuuis,

Hore is a description of the mysterious personage : "The dorsal extremities constituted a veritable gallery of art,"—this we presume, is Louvre—"on the back were painted the portraits of beautifal women (Isis was evidently not on conquest bent) which marked their author as a man of talent. The works were those of artists of fame clearly recognisable from the tact that oopies of paintings of note were among them"—the Loovre galleries in miniature, in faot.

"The back was covered with the portraits of angels (angels sitting for tbeir photographs is good) surmounted by an inscription in Goth o oharaoters, tho alignment of which was nothing short of marvellous : 'My soul's desire is to go baok to mamma,' said the inscription." Isis praying to the gods to return her to a tender mother's oare—evidently pining for her niche in the Lonvie galleries—with the custodians watching the clook for the hour of release, mikes a grand final touch to the ensemble. But alas ! the conoluding sentence seems to imply that discovery is as tar away as ever. The words are, "This sandwich man stubbornly refased to give his name."

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S Carib Prinoe, with passengers and general cargo, arrived at Manchester from A'exandria on the 17ih ins'-.
Tbe S.S. Asiatic Priooe, with passengers and general cargo. left. Malta on the 19th inBt., and is dae at Alexandria on Friday.
The Curard 8 8. Tyria has arrived from Volo and will sail for Liverpool iu a few days.

div.head: Cairo Season
CONTINENTAL'S "OFFICIAL" OPENING
div.p: The official season of the Grand Continental Hote', Cairo, may be said to. commence on the 26th inst. with the inauguration of the newly, fitted grill-room and the first appearance of an excellent mixed string band from Milan, from which we are promised a nightly musical treatment. Meanwhile the hotel is gradually filling op and the day is very near when those who have not engaged rooms beforehand will have to meet with a suave but disconcerting "Very Borry, but every room is takeD."

Among those who are present at this hotel lire Prince and Princess Ali Fathy, Daninos Pasha, Capt. Zizinis, Bernard Pasha, President Pruni&res, Mr. and Mrs. Parker. Mr. Sidney Wells, Rev. and Mrp. E. J. Hardy (senior Church of England Chaplain to the Poroes). Rostowitz Bey and Mrs. Rostowitz, Lt. Col. and Mrs. Drummond Hay, Lieut, and Mrs. Langhton. Major and Mrs. Campbell, and Mr. P. F. Back.

Among those who have booked rooms and are expected in the coarse of the week are Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Aird, Mr. Danbar Kilbnrn, Mt. and Mrs. A. F. Barnes, Major Rotheram.Mr. Morse, and twenty-eight tourists who will arrive by the steam-yaoht Argonaut on the 26th iust.

It will also interest our readers to know that Syer, wh^m we may style Egypt's professional billiard ohampion, has again resumed bis duties as marker and promises to provide the habitues of the Continental Hotel with even better displays than he gave last year.

div.head: LATIN PATRIARCH OF JERUSALEM
div.p: HIS GRACE MGR. CANA88BI.

The Throne of the Latin Patriarchate of Jerusalem, vacant sires the death of the late lamented MoDsignor Piavi, who had oooupied that exalted position for sixteen years, has at length been filled, and au end thus put to no small measure of anxiety in Latin Oriental politico, by the appointment cf His Grace Monsignor Caroaspei, Romish Bishop of Nnxos.

Tbe new Patriarch, Philippe Camassei, was born in Rome on the 14th September, 1848. He studied theology in a Roman seminary, and passed in theology and canon law. Ordained a priest on the 12th April, 1872, he was appointed Censor of the Liturgical Academy, Reotor of the College of the Propaganda in 1890, and domestic prelate of the Pope in 1897. He was consecrated an Archbishop of Naxos and Primate of the Cyoladea in May, and entered upon his episcopal duties a month later.

The new Patriaroh is a great favourite at Constantinople, and was decorated in Angnst 1904 with the Oamanieh. His tolerant attitude towards the Orthodox Greeks during bis tenure of the Bishoorio of Naxo3 no doubt led to his preferment to a post involving snob grave responsibilities and delioate negotiations. E-joying as he does the goodwill of the Orthodox Greeks, it is to be earnestly hoped that this jndioious nomination will mark the dawning of a new era wherein the w.arrings of rival ohurch^s militant may oease, or at any rate in which the speotaole of snoh scenes of tumult as take place between Latin and Greek shall no longer disgrace the holy sanotuary.

As a matter of foot, the Greeks have the right of precedence, as Javenal, who was the first Greek Patriaroh, appointed by the Counoil of Chalcedon in 451, had as many as eighty- eight successors before a Latin Patriaroh was appointed. Prior to Javenal, Jerusalem was no more than a Bishopric suEfragant on Croiarea, the administrative capital of the Roman province. The famous split o/er the question of the Filicqae began in 819, when Thomas was Greek Patriarch ; and it was in 1099 that the Pope's Lpgate Daimbert, Archbishop of Pisa, was appointed the first Latin Patriarch. In 1369 the Franoisoans of the Holy Land aserp- ed the jarisdiotion of the Latin Patriarch, whose position until 1847 was insignificant. Pi as IX., however, restored the dignity and appointed Mgr. Joseph Valerga, a Genoese Dootor ot Theology who was also an Oriental lingaist, speaking, inter alia, Tarkish,Chaldean, and Arabic. He it was who organised the missions. He died in 1872, and was succeeded by Mgr. Viuceati Braoco, who reigned thirteen years.
Since the death of Mgr. Piavi the Loonm Tenens has been the Patriarchal Vioar M^r. Piccardo.

div.head: IMPORTANT WORKS AT PORT SAID.
div.p: It is stated that the Suez Canal Company have decided to give over to private coutno- tors the building of an arsenal and a graving dock on the Asiatic shore of the Cana). A British firm is said to have secured the contract, which will run into several millions of francs. There is also some talk of a tunnel beneath the Canal with an eleotrio railway.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Daring the week ending Isst Sunday fonr oases of plague were reported in the whole of Egypt, one at Alexandria, one ot Suez, and two in Tahta district.
Since January 1 529 cases ot plague were reported, against 225 in the corresponding period of 1905 and 825 in 1904.

div.head: CHANGES AMONG OFFICIALS.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Larnaca, November 15.
The four summer mouths, usually so destitute of new*, have not been without tbeir record of small events of interest. Among the official ohanges that have taken place, the following may be noted : —

Sir Joseph Hutchinson, late Chief Justioe of Cyprus,and Lady Hatchinson left the Island in July last for England, and are by this time settled in their new home at Colombo ; he having been promoted to the Ch;ef Justiceship of Ceylon. His post in Cyprns was temporarily filled by Mr. F. Parker, District Judge at Nicosia, pending the arrival of Mr. C. R. Tyser, formerly Puisne Judge, who is now appointed to succeed Sir Joseph Hutchinson.

" The new Chief Secretary, Major Chanson, R.E., with h'8 wife and children, has just arrived and oommenced his new duties. Major Chansen, who has not had previoos experience in Colonial administration, is however regarded as an exceptionally capable officer and latterly has held the important appointment of Secretary to the Imperial Defence Committee. Captain FeildeD, Looal Commandant of Police at Famagusta, has resigned and returned to England, and Mr. Borill, for many years an active aud oapable Inspector of Police, has proceeded to West Africa, whete he has received an appointment of a similar nature. Mr. P. Mayall has left Cyprus after completing a term of three years as head master of the English School at Nicosia.

The small English community ha9 this summer sustained a sad loss by the death of Mrs. Day, wife ofj Mr. Bert Day, general manager of the Cyprus Government Railway, with whom general sympathy has been felt Departure of the Elreno.

It is much to be regretted that the excellent little S.S. Eirene, belonging to Messrs. Dimoka and Co., of Athens, has oeased calling at Cyprus. This well found little vesssl had for some mouths made a regular-itinerary from Athens, calling evsry ten days at Alexandria, Limassol, Lamaist, aud Port Said, and it is a distinct misfortuue to travellers to aud from Cyprus, that she has now gooe to other parts.

Apropos of this may we venture to hope that the owners of the S.S. Lefkosis, now p'ying between Cyprus and Egypt, will take the proper measures to have this boat regularly oleanei. At present one's feelings are oatraged by the want of "spio and spanness" which prevails everywhere on deck. Making every allowance for the natnral contrast one might expeot to find after leaving one of our first-class liners, one may yet, without undue oaptionsness, urge the more frequent application of water at least—if fresh paint is out of the question. The use of cotton waste and water appears to be unknown, and consequently throughout the vessel the white paint has become a dingy grey, and ooal dust envelopes the ship in a shroud of unre lieved griminess.

The appearance of rope?, caDvas, and taokle generally does not inspire oonfidenoe, and one feels inolined to ask whether at stated times, or at al), the crew are made to go throngh any form of boat drill, and whether the boats and ship's gear not in daily nse are properly tested at regalar intervals. Io other respects the Lefkosia is au improvement on the old Bell boats, and the food and attendance are quite fair. Both the condition and smart, clean appearance cf the ship's furniture and tackle are however in need of more constant and searching attention.
King's Birthday.

The King's Birthday was, as nsnal, celebrated by a parade of the Cyprns Military Polioe and their inspeotion by His Excellency the High Commissioner at Nicosia. A ball was given in the evening at Government Honse, which was numerously attended by Government officials, and by the leading members of the Tarki h and Greek communities.

The quinquenuial elections to the Legislative Assembly ware held in October, and a substantial majority was recorded in favour of the Bishop ot Kitiom's party. A large orop of petitions has so far been the most oonspicuoas result.
Building at hamagusta.

Building has been proceeding rapidly at Famagusta. The Imperial Ottoman Bank w ll shortly be installed in a fine honse specially built for its branch there, and next to it is a large building emoted for the accommodation of the newly-formed Agrionltural Bank. Two new houses are being completed on what is called "the Ridge"; the one being the private residence of Sir William Willcooks, or for the general manager of the Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Company, the other for the manager of the Agrionltural Bank.

div.head: SPECULATIVE EGYPT.
div.p: The "Bosphore Egyptien" remarks The commercial development of Egypt has made it a land of speculation. The publio speculates over everything : snpar, oorn, land, mires, cotton, and what not. Tbe brokers are legion ; in foot, there are too many of them. R<-al estate agents are innumerably, tbe bonne buildings shelter a veritable army. In Europe we hear of the rapid acquisition of huge fortunes. The business and commercial world of Egypt sees the process in case after case, for the taste for gain*has grown enormoasly in the valley ot the Nile. We live in a sort of stock exohange Arcadia, where gambling, not to speak of theft, are pursued and veiled under the oloak of speculation. *

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: Prinoe Fuad Pasha, who arrived from Europo yesterday, left for Cairo in the afternoon.
Hussein Pasha Moharrem, A. D. C. to the Khedive, returned to Alexandria yesterday afternoon from Cairo, whore he had been making arrangements for the removal' of the Khedivial Maieh.

Oar Paris Correspondent writes :—The Earl ofRoselyn, who has recently been staying in Paris, informs a correspondent tbutr'be will be proceeding for a long stay i i Egypt at the beginning of December with a party of friends. His lordship, who is looking exceedingly well, has crowded a good deal into his 87 years of existence. After running through a very handsome fortune he tamed his attention to the Press and stage nutters, aotiog. as all the world kuowa, under the nom deth&tre of "Mr. James Er-kine." When the war broke out in South A frica he was early on the scene and combined the joint occupations cf journalist and trooper with no small snooess. Hesoomd a great triumph by cabling to the "Daily Mail" the fall of Pretoria two days before it aotually took place. Lord Rosslyn has married two wives, the first being the daughter of Mr. Robert Viner, a well-known Yorkshireman and sportsman, and the second being Mise Anna Robinson, an Amsrioan actress who has for some years been known as a frequenter of Monte Carlo. Neither of these unions has been particularly happy.
Lewa Bernard Bey, Financial Secretary to the Sudan Government, and Mrs. Bernard are loaving Cairo for Khartoum on the 26th inst.
Colonel Nadand, who has seoured the concession for the export of Jordan water to the United 8tates, is passingtbrrugh Alexandria ou his way to New York. He is leaving tomorrow by the Hohenznllern.
The fdlowing offioers of the 3rd Coldstream Guards have been granted leave of absence : C i'oael Granville Smith, Lieut RL. Dawson, and Lieut. E H. Tollemache; and Major W. P. G Mylrea, A.S.C.
Mr. MacGillivray, manager of the Bank of Abyssinia, is expected at Cairo in the near future.
Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Aird arrived from Europe yesterday, and have left for Cairo.

div.head:
State Of Morocco
Going From Bad to Worse
Intervestion Expected

div.p: The condition of things is going from bad to worse. Europeans are looking forward to intervention on the part of France and Spain. It is understood that both countries are making preparations to avoid being taken unaware* when the moment for action arrives. (lieuter)

div.head:
The Borr Raid
How It Was Frustrated

div.p: Ferreira's followers were worn ont and disheartened and offered no resistance. The trouble oaueed by them was altogether disproportionate to their strength. Troops formed a cordon of lr0 miles, from the Orange River to the Kalahari desert, overcoming immense difficulties, soaroity of water, heat, and dust storms. They dispensed with transport and lived on country. (Reuter)

The newspapers, including the Conservative Pres?, continue to publish articles expressing intense dissatisfaction with the situation at home and abroad, which they attribute largely to the Emperor's constant personal intervention. They stiongly urge the necessity for remedy. Prinoe von Bulow's speech has not allayed the popular discontent with the foreign policy. (Reuter)

The King and Queen of Denmark have arrived, and were received cordially. In bis toast at the banquet, the Emperor said that he was convinced that intimate relations would be maintained for the greatest good of both nations. The King replied that he hoped their relations would become more and more cordial. (Havas)

Forty 8offrBgettes, headed by General French's sister and Mrs. Despard, made a fresh demonstration in Palace Yard. Mrs. Despard and another lady moonted the pedestal of a statue. The latter lady harangued the meeting. 8be was arrested. The polios refased to arrest Mrs. Despard despite her entreaties. (Reuter)

The 8.S. Jennie rammed and sank the S.8. Dix here last night. Forty-one persons were drowned. The Jennie resoned 39. Many women end ohildren were trapped in their cabins. A terrible panic ooonrred. (Peuter)
A sharp earthquake shock was felt along the whole of the west coast this afternoon. (Reuter)
Tbe contract in connection with the Anglo- Rusfiian loan to Persia is still DDsigned owing to the popular objeotion to all foreign loans, bat ca*h is not forthcoming for the internal loan. • (Reuter)

div.head: British School of Archeology in Egypt
div.p: Need for Present Support

Sir Robert Hensley presided at the annua' muring of the British School of Archrmlrgy in Egypt and the Egyptian Research Auoonnt, which took place at the University College, London, last Saturday week. The Chairman, in opening, spoke of the flourishing state of the reboot. He also referred to the greatly increased interest wh'ch is taken in Egypt, and to the demand that the prosperity of that country has made for young men trained in a knowledge of the language and with a personal acquaintance with the best specimens of the inhabitants and with the districts wbioh the ordinary traveller gets no acquaintance with. That was preoiaely the kind of training which the British Bchool of Archaeology was capable cf affording in a way in which, perhaps, no other agency was capable of pffordirg it. Lord Cromer himself was personally very well disposed towards the School, and gave it his cordial support. (Cheers.) Statements showing the great progress of the school were made by Dr. J. H. Walker and Mrs. Petrie, the hon. secretaries, and it was Announced that Lord Cromer bad consented to he patron of the school. The Treasurer, Mr. Hilton Price, gave a most satisfactory account of the finances of the school and rssearch account. Professor Flinders Petrie, in the oourse of an address, said it was rarely that a new movement, for scientific research had become established so qnir-kly and decisively as the British School of Archie >!ogy in Egypt. When in May last year the necessity for snob an organization WAB forced upon him by external oiroom- stances he could not antioipate that so substantial an instrument of resaaroh would be so ppeedi'y entrusted to their committee by the public. Within a year and a half the oolleotion of over £3,COO had shown what a hearty interest was felt in the recovery of the history and civilization of Egypt. Their assured positioD for future work needed now to be thoroughly maintained, in order to make it oomparable with the riohly endowed French Sohool, the many official enterpriser of German Oriental work, and the Royal undertakings of Italy. The publio must always remember that other Governments regarded the historical researches of their countries as matters of pnblio concern ; while England alone left its workers to struggle for the means of Egyptian studies. The labour of collecting with one hand while spending with the otheT was, indeed, almost impossible; and but for the unceasing work of organiz'ng and correspondence carried on by his wife (cheers) there would have been no snch meeting as that which was held that day. The direction of hundreds of workmen the management of the large collections, the publication of full memoirs of results were alone enough to require undivided attention ; and, while thauking them most heartily for the splendid response to the critical position in which their work stood last year, he mast trast that they would remember how impossible all that activity in Egypt would be without their support and that of their friends. The work of the past season proved the richest historical harvest that he had known. The Hyksos oamp and cemetery, the oity of Raamies,and the temple and town of Ooias had all consolidated their vague impressions and scanty literary statements in a most satisfactory manner. The three students who went ont with him largely contributed to their resnltg, and his wife drew 50 plates; they were able to keep two camps at work, and altogether to examine Bix sites. This year there wonld be six students at work, one of whom, Mrs. Firth, had done admirable drawings for previous volumes at the Mastabas of Sakkara ; while another stndent had had mnsenm experience at Edinburgh, and had the sarotion of the Education Department to include Egyptian work in his studies. The ground ou which they were permitted to work was in three districts. First, they should begin on the desert between Giza and Abusir ; tombs of the first, the second, and third dynasties were already known there, and it was the most promising site available for ascertaining the civilization between the Great ages of the first and fourth dynasties. Whether there was a great deoline in the interval waB or e of the urgent problems in history. Secondly, they might work between AsBiout and Sohag with a view to trying for any light between the seventh and 11th dynasties, as tombs of the ninth dynasty were known there. Lastly, the temple site of the important oity of Athribis ought to be found, and perhaps they might search lor it. At eaoh of these sites the need of work was orgeat. Not only was there the ceaseless destruction carried on by the native, and the almost equally destrnotive excavations of the licensed digger, who did not work scientifically or publish all his resnlts; but in the last year or two there had be|fn a fearsome activity in selling off Government lands to ppecalators. The great oemetpry of Heliopolis was sold; the cemetery of Tell el Yehndiyeh with the Hyksos graves was sold, and only by a rare ohance was he allowed to wo»k in it ; the town of Goshen was sold, and work there was impossible ; land below the pyramid hill was sold ; most of the site of Athnbis was sold. In every direction the chances of recovering history were disappearing fnr ever. Their small resources of a few thousand poonds were as nothing in view of purchasing sites ; and they were not in a position to enter into the speculative market of buying for resale. Nor could they assume that any representations of students ooold affect the policy of the lands department, which already overrode the department of antiquities. Thsy mast face the fact that, while debarred by one department from working on the most important sites, they were seeing the ground rapidly ont from nnder their feet by the other department. The only possible oonrse seemed to he to work ont the sites ia danger as rapidly as possible ; not to'spend a pound or a day over olearing up monuments which were already recognized and not in danger, bat to exhaust as quickly as they could thegrrund which might soon pass irrevocably into speculative hands. They did not ask them and the publio in general for any long-oontinned support ; the next few years would see the larger part of the openings for work finally closed. That was not like a snljeot of natural soienoe which coold generally be done in the next generation ; here they wanted to pnt in as many salvage men as possible before the ohanoes of resone had vanished. Let them try to concentrate all their resources on Egypt for a few years, knowing that there would be but little need ot such work ten years henoe— the history wonld have vanished for ever by that time. Suoh was the prospeot, suoh were their olaims to day, and the response in the past year gave him hopes that they might yet see more workers and more means for the English share of the rescue of Egyptian history. (Load cheers.)

div.head: Crossing the Sahara
div.p: British Resident's Adventurous Journey

Interesting letters have been reoeived from Mr. Hans Viacher, British Resident at Knka, Lake Chad, who is now undertaking a danger- ons journey through the forbidden hinterland of Tripoli across the great Sahara to Lake Chad. In the course of the description of his jonrney Mr. Visoher says : —"In the mountains of Gharian I found to my astonishment people living in subterranean dwellings. Through entrances ten yards loDg and one broad we came npon a square courtyard, which is in reality a great hole open to the sky. Upon this all the rooms and stables oonverge. The rooms were very dark, and there were no wiodowp, bat the most absolute cleanliness prevailed. Round the courtyard runs a wall which protects the dwelling underneath." At this point Mr. Vischer met Djamy Bey, the Torkish officer who was to accompany him to Marzuk. Tbe Bey bad with him an Arab Sbeikh and a large caravan. Taking with him some of the worst of his blaoks Mr. Visoher and Djamy Bey proceeded towards the desert of the Hammada, following Bar+h's route via Mifda, the remainder of- the oaravan going on behind. Oa the march from Tabonra to the Hammada Desert Mr. Visoher found many Roman remains. "I made," continues Mr. Vischer, "some interesting observations in the desert. The difference between the night and day temperature is always at least 20deg. (Celsius). Beyond Gharian the gronud rises up to the hills, where fig and olive groves lie among Roman ruins and underground villages. As we approached Marzuk we came across lovely stretches of petrified forest" Writing from Marz ik on Aag. 24th, Mr. Vischer eays : "We arrived here yesterday. I was received with great honour by the Governor of Fezzan, and a beautiful house has been placed at my disposal. 1 reoeived an offijial invitation to the enthronement of the Saltan, and a review of the garrison was held." Another letter, dated Mnrzak, Sept. 21st, emphasizes the great friendliness of the people, and says that the oaravan is on the point of starting for Lake Chad. Messages hsd been Rent on by the Pasha at Marzuk to two headmen at Tiberti to oonvoy the British Resident. "Within three days," writes Mr. Visoher, "we hope to be in Gatro, in twenty days in Bilma, and in forty days in Knka. Everything is in good order, and the members of the oaravan are perfeotly quiet. I leave at Marzuk Djamy Bey, who accompanied me to that point."

Candidates for clerkships mast have the Secondary Certificate of Education and, if snooessfal, will be employed at L.E. 7 per month.
